message: If you are starting a Web Application project today, which technology stack are you going to use? and Why?

data.message: Depends on the application size! Sure for me I will use Microsoft ASP.NET Stack and based on the project requirement & size I will choose either asp.net mvc or web forms. If it's an enterprise application with some CMS I will go for MS SharePoint
The reason I choose asp.net that is my area of expertise :)
Emad Elwany I think this is the most buzzword to word density I have seen in one comment :D
Emad Elwany NodeJS ecosystem is amazing, it is one of the technologies that I haven't had chance to use it in any serious stuff, but I think it is amazing how things are progressing on its end

My latest project used this stack

Python Flask as web platform
SQLAlchemy for ORM
MySQL DB
Knockout.JS for front end
Linux server \ nothing prevents it from running on Windows though

I liked the Python Flask model of very thin plugins, so you can always only use what you need.
WOW You are the only one I know who used TypeScript for NodeJS application, this needs to be talked about further more :D
Say hi to Anders Hejlsberg
This project I was working on had a very extensive use of Knockout, it was very good, we didn't consider Angular though it was an overkill for our case, we only wanted a good MVVM style binding

Depend on the project case and the problem we are trying to solve. but in general if i need a web application i would go for Ruby-on-Rails and if there is any real time feature required I would add Nodejs+Socket.io MySQL DB works 99% for my needs while I can go for PostgreSQL in very specific needs.
I haven't gone far in Angular but i used Backbone in many projects and i really like it a lot. However I wanna go a bit deeper in Angular to see the best use case for using it.

Front End:
Ractive.js (not to be confused with reactive.js)
PubSub.js
TypeScript

Windows Backend:
MVC 5
Web API 2
SQL Server 
Elastic Search
RabbitMQ

Linux Backend:
Hack/HHVM
RethinkDB or PostgreSQL
Elastic Search
RabbitMQ

- Ruby with sinatra for personal projects, with maybe 2-3 really good ruby developers

- Ruby on rails for work projects, with maybe a mid or entry level developers on the team.

- Emberjs ( previously spinejs and cappuccino ) won't replace cappuccino anytime soon.

- Erlang is indispensable if we have any realtime components

- Redis as a message bus, depending on our requirements we either persist on it or elsewhere.

- MySQL is our database of choice

- OCaml where we need an external support utility. We went from Ruby to C then finally OCaml

- We use our internal metrics tools they measure AARRR metrics plus mixpanel

- We use Google analytics but our own reporting (weekly mail digests, super neat)

- Capistrano for deployment

- Utility scripts in ruby for server management

- No server monitoring, now linode added that for us, so we use this from linode and we're a long time happy camper there.

- Nginx and Thin for all our production deployments.

- Bootstrap for work projects

- Compass css for personal projects

- Zepto.js for large 3rd party javascript projects, for smaller ones we have an in-house library. 

- jQuery for anything else, designing for mobile is a byproduct of our process not a first priority since most of what we build or what I'm personally interested in building in my personal time is far from usable on a small screen.

- Git for version control, we track everything from server configuration to code and host at bitbucket.

Edit: More signal, less noise.
ASP.NET web forms and some kind of code generator like codesmith. Probably Telerik controls. No need for fancy buzz words or JS frameworks unless you are making a user portal with cool UI
I am not smart enough to understand JS frameworks - so I don't use them either.

Web framework: Django when I have the choice. I like the ORM, admin UI & lots of reusable apps. For very small apps & services I use bottle. Bottle also has better support for websockets & SSE. I'm thinking of trying NodeJS.

Scripting: Python, but I tried NodeJS lately for its async capabilities & it was awesome. AutoHotKey if it can be done with it

DB: SQLite is good because it's simple. I like Postgres very much because of its GIS features & DB types. Rob Conery gave a great session just scratching the surface of Postgres. SQL Server is fine, but I can't say I'm a fan. I'm still thinking of trying Mongo, specially its features & Redis later.

Front-end: I used Angular & Knockout. Both has advantages & disadvantages. 

Desktop apps: currently I prefer PyQt because it's cross-platform.
golang+angularjs

This is what I use now. I'd probably consider reusing most of them just because they get the job done and my company has proper setup for getting them up quickly:

The tools:

http://gurustop.net/blog/2014/04/01/tools-i-use-when-developing-on-net/
ASP.NET MVC , why Because easy to done tasks and easy to maintenance and more secure and more performance ......
ملاحظ مفيش جافا خالص
Asp.Net MVC wesh :D
Python Via Django - Although I am not so good at Python or even Django .

طب خليني أعيد صياغة السؤال (أو يمكن أسأل سؤال مختلف شوية):
عند بداية مشروع جديد .. هل:
- تختار التكنولوجيا اللي عارفها
ولا
- بتدور علي أفضل تكنولوجيا مناسبة للمشروع وتتعلمها وتستخدمها
غالبا بيبقى اللي تغلبه العبه Principle
مشروع وفيه فريق و ديد لاين ؟ مظنش سهل اتعلم له

بعد إعادة صياغة السؤال ، بروح مع إجابة إني بدور على أفضل حاجة وأتعلمها ، صحيح لسه مطبقتش لحد دلوقت الموضوع ده بس هو ده اللي هعمله ، وبالنسبة للديد لاين الحقيقة أنا مبشتغلش أصلاً غير وانا تحت ضغط ولو مفيش ضغط بأخر الشغل لحد ما يبقى في ضغط في الوقت :D
